2025.11.text: on an EasyJet flight, and they were flying down to the south of Spain

2029.91.text: to what is essentially a desert to a place where they use too much water

2035.46.text: to play golf for two days, and flew back.

2041.63.text: And I thought this was just awful on so many levels,

2057.57.text: You can justify the necessity to work, to be able to continue

2099.60.text: I'm a hypocrite. We're all hypocrites. It's a matter of degrees.

2102.97.text: The point is I think we're living in a corrupt system that's designed

2109.63.text: to do the wrong thing. So how do you live in a corrupt system?

2113.40.text: For example, it's now easier to get us bottled water

2118.54.text: than it is to bring a jug of water and some cups.

2121.77.text: It's now easier for us to be provided with that.

2127.11.text: We've designed a system. I understand why. I'm very grateful for the water,

2131.54.text: but I'm not really sure I need water in a bottle

2134.63.text: when I can get it from the tap upstairs for free, or for cheap,

2137.71.text: and it's healthier and better for everybody.

2139.94.text: So we're living in this corrupt system. I think it's

2144.26.text: about trying to navigate your way as healthily through this corruption as possible,

2148.85.text: and sometimes you have to go this way.

2165.11.text: If it's not Red Bull it's someone else. It's Jaegermeister.

2181.69.text: and the venue was sponsored by Philip Morris,

2192.71.text: Ashtray. Philip Morris ashtray. And the Gauloises people were like

2196.97.text: "Oh a Philip Morris ashtray. Okay quick, let's put up a Gauloises banner"

2201.91.text: and they were like "Oh they put up a banner,

2222.03.text: I guess the content of your music though is there to cut through some of that

2230.31.text: It would be nice to feel like that. I feel like we should prick the bubble.

2264.94.text: "Heyyy, hey it's cool. Take it easy. It's safe. Everything's alright."

2286.66.text: The music is everywhere. We're surrounded by music that's telling us

2516.29.text: I think 100% needs to go to the musicians.

2520.88.text: I think 100% to us. The responsibility is us that make it.

2524.69.text: I don't even believe in the idea of an audience anymore.

2529.54.text: I think this is a good example: who here sometimes makes music?

2539.91.text: You see, that's easily the majority of people here.

2544.89.text: So you all roughly know. You all have these questions ourselves.

2551.34.text: The audience is like fans. I hate the idea of fans.

2559.46.text: It feels like part of the capitalist way oc tontaining people,

2563.85.text: and saying "Okay I'm going to sell you something, and treat you like a homogenous blob."

2568.34.text: That's why I think it's a real trap to make music for other people as well.

2617.17.text: I think we're actually reaching the end of the audience.

2626.46.text: It's just a conversation between people doing different things

2672.31.text: their parasols and banners and ashtrays in order to be seen

2679.23.text: and this talk is all about your manifesto, and I was wondering

2684.11.text: in the same way whereas an artist like a painter has to really rely

2688.49.text: on self promotion these days in order to get this work out there

2691.69.text: into galleries and things like that. Would you consider your manifesto

2695.97.text: and the fact that you wrote it in a more artistic stance

2703.97.text: that bought you some form of self promotion in order to get your work out there?

2711.86.text: Was that the idea behind the manifesto?

2716.89.text: No. There's a number of reasons I wrote it, but one of the big reasons

2723.03.text: I wrote it was because the dogma manifesto in film,

2730.43.text: and I thought there was something really interesting about

2733.91.text: publicly committing yourself to a set of principles,

2737.29.text: and what that might to do the work. So that encouraged me

2740.17.text: to formulate it. As Wishmountain I always wrote music like this.

2744.60.text: So from 1990 or 1991 this is how I wrote music.

2750.89.text: This is how I've written music for the last 25 years.

2755.60.text: But there was a point about making it public, which was about ideas.

2759.29.text: So for me, I'm not really interested in self promotion in the sense that

2766.23.text: if I wanted to be famous, there are much easier ways of doing it

2770.31.text: than making records out of bombs that nobody really wants to listen to.

2776.91.text: And you know if I've made music out of a bomb where 3 people died

2781.09.text: there's not a huge audience for that.

2783.28.text: It's not something you would play at a dinner party.

2788.31.text: There's a much easier path that I could have taken.

2792.57.text: I've turned easily between 10 and 15 million pounds

2796.63.text: worth of advertising over the past 25 years.

2799.71.text: The very first proper big advert I turned down

2802.86.text: was worth 4 million quid just on its own.

2806.03.text: So there's other ways of doing that.

2810.83.text: One of the reasons I do these kinds of things is about ideas,

2815.31.text: and about meeting people. It's not really again about me because,

2818.94.text: again I could earn a lot more money by doing a show

2822.34.text: instead of sitting and talking, but I think it's important.

2826.91.text: All the best things happen when people come together actually.

2831.11.text: That's how we stop the system. That's how we change things.

2836.97.text: So I'm interested in the risk of me sitting here

2842.46.text: and saying some of these things, because sometimes people stand up

2846.11.text: and they tell you you're wrong, or they give you another example,

2855.23.text: I've had 3 hours sleep. I'd quite like to be in bed, or in a bar,

2859.51.text: or something like that, but for me this stuff is important.

2863.68.text: I got into music to change the world in some ways.

2868.46.text: I know it's a naive thing to say

2870.31.text: and there's not many people that would probably admit to that,

2873.63.text: but that's part of my motivation.

2877.80.text: And it terms of promotion, if you're thinking about promotion

2881.51.text: and all that kind of stuff, for me there are two ways.

2884.63.text: There's one way which is that "I want to make money,

2887.29.text: and I'm going to do whatever I can to promote myself"

2889.89.text: and that involves changing yourself to fit a system that exists,

2894.49.text: so making your music more and more simple maybe,

2898.03.text: and making it sound like everybody else,

2901.60.text: and being prepared to take sponsorship and whatever it takes.

2909.63.text: I know a lot of people, contemporaries of mine,

2912.43.text: that have chosen to dilute what they do to be able to get more money

2915.86.text: and to get fame, and houses or whatever it is. So that's one way.

2920.20.text: And the other idea for me is about ideas. That's something that's really

2924.80.text: fundamental to the creative process, is "What's the idea?"

2931.11.text: It sounds bizarre, but one of the proudest moments of my life is

2939.05.text: that 7, 8 years later, nearly 3 times a week

2944.63.text: I talk about a pig that was born on a farm in Kent,

2948.91.text: that would have otherwise just been sausages,

2951.66.text: and would have just been a disposable moment,

2954.02.text: but people still want to talk about this pig,

2956.46.text: Where did it come from? Its life. And for me that's the idea.

2962.37.text: That record really was about listening.

2965.54.text: It was listening to something we don't normally hear.

2968.54.text: You know there were 396,000 pigs killed in America this month.

2974.46.text: And there will be next month. And there are 72 million chickens

2978.69.text: a day killed in America. I mean vast numbers of farm animals killed.

2983.49.text: I'm not vegetarian, but the number and scale that we kill

2986.74.text: of these animals is disgusting I think. And so the ability with my music

2991.66.text: to be able to remember one of these animals from 8 years ago

2997.77.text: and to listen to that life, and hear it being born and hear it breathe,

3002.34.text: and that act of remembrance for me feels like a powerful idea,

3009.80.text: and that's the thing that I'm interested in promoting.

3013.06.text: I'm interested in promoting the idea of listening, of tolerance,

3018.46.text: of kindness, of dialogue, of listening.
